fields.description:
Hi

We use Puppet to manage all our Atlassian products as services.
But since Bamboo 5.1 there is no longer a single init script (bamboo.sh) that we can call. 

This breaks our way of working and results in a loss of service towards our internal customers (Bamboo must now always be started and stopped manually).

Will this single init script come back?

Best regards,
Peter
fields.summary: Lack of a Single Init script

fields.description:
I'm using Git.

If I create a plan that has a trigger of any kind (say, one that causes the build to kick off once a day at midnight on the master branch), and I enable automatic branch creation on that same plan, then every time someone creates any new branch (that is, pushes a branch that previously did not exist) in my Git repository Bamboo will immediately start a build for that new branch.

This is obviously very bad and not what I want.  What I want is for (a) the build to run on the master branch automatically once every day at midnight, and separately (b) branches to be created automatically by Bamboo so that users can manually start builds on their personal branches.

Having Bamboo automatically start builds like this means I can't use automated branch creation on any plan that has a trigger.
fields.summary: Build starts for every new branch when auto-branching and a trigger are on the same plan

fields.description:
While HipChat is great, our company widely uses Google Apps, including Google Talk (aka Hangouts) beyond the software team that uses Bamboo.

It would be great to have Google Talk notifications from Bamboo OnDemand as well, or perhaps more general XMPP support would suffice.  (It is unclear to me what the Instant Messaging Address is used for if not for that - perhaps that is meant for XMPP, and Google just doesn't support that).

See [Question on Atlassian Answers question|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/225607/bamboo-notifications-to-google-talk]

Also, this is at least [documented for hosted Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+Bamboo+to+use+Google+Talk+for+Instant+Messaging], so hopefully the answer isn't just to use HipChat...
fields.summary: Google Talk Notifications

I have included some logs for the two relevant jobs. I can provide more data if you want to.
What happened here was that job 1 failed, as it tried to execute smoke tests while job 2 was deploying (i.e. restarting services).

In the latest Bamboo versions (5.x) we added the AgentHome/xml-data/build-dir/logs directory to store the build logs on the remote agent, but it seems like there are some issues:

1) For Windows remote agents the log files show as 0KB for size, and when one tries to open the logs files in a text editor, there is a process holding the file (some editors show the content and start adding time stamp text, others fail to open the files). For Mac agents, the files are empty.
2) When running a build expiry, Bamboo doesn't delete the log files from here (from the remote agent).
fields.summary: Remote agent build logs aren't stored and cleaned properly

fields.description:
Some customers would like to have greater control over (essentially) firewall settings of EC2 instances (for example IP-lock inbound rules to the location of Bamboo server).
Currently, Bamboo does not let them do it - it will allow only new rules,  changes to existing rules (SSH,RDP,Tunnel) will be reverted.

We should add a configuration option that would prevent Bamboo from fully controlling  rules in existing groups. With this option enabled, security group rule sync would be slightly changed:
 * if the group didn't exist, inbound rules would be added as they are today.
 * if the group already existed, SSH and RDP settings wouldn't be touched. 
 * if the group already existed, tunnel port rule would have to exist, but could be IP-locked. An IP-locked rule would be logged at DEBUG level.
fields.summary: Inbound/Outbound EC2 Security rules should not be tightly controlled

fields.description:
According to https://developer.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOODEV/Bamboo+REST+Resources#BambooRESTResources-BuildQueueService I should be able to delete things from the queue using the api. However, it appears that the DefaultServlet is getting in the way and looking for the actual resources on disk. Before mucking around with configs, this is the symptom. *POST something to the queue (I am sure it's queued).* $ curl -X POST http://rjames:monkeys@localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/queue/WIL-BT {code:html} Manual buildrjames@ma-dt-rj:bamboo-test {code} *DELETE it from the queue.* $ curl -X DELETE http://rjames:monkeys@localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/queue/WIL-BT-341 {code:html} Apache Tomcat/7.0.40 - Error report

HTTP Status 405 - Method Not Allowed

type Status report

message Method Not Allowed

description The specified HTTP method is not allowed for the requested resource.

Apache Tomcat/7.0.40

{code} I *think* this is because of the doDelete method in the catalina DefaultServlet container. Because... If I set readonly=false and post a new job, then create a file matching the uri, I can get the server to actually delete the file via the DELETE request(!!!!), but the PLAN-KEY-BUILD is still there. This leads me to believe that the DefaultServlet is not passing the request through... or however this works. :-) I really don't know how the internals of java servlet containers work so well... But... regardless, it would be great if the API worked as documented. thanks!
fields.summary: DELETE /rest/api/latest/queue/PLAN-KEY-BUILDNUMBER Throws Method not found 405

This issue is to track the investigation where a customer had all instances disabled but one, a Linux one, a then for a week, a Windows EC2 instance was used until it was disabled manually.

Can it be avoided it with the bidding preferences?

fields.description:
We currently have the desire to use different version numbering schemes, based on the Git branch, e,g, the master branch would be 1.0.0.${bamboo.buildNumber}, while the develop branch would be 1.0.0.snapshot or 1.0.0.latest.

Right now, I'm using separate plans for each branch, but would like to use the branching feature within a single plan.  Seems like one of these two options would suffice:

1. The ability to create a plan variable, whose value is ${bamboo.buildNumber}.  Then, the master branch could use this, while the develop branch overrides it with the static label.  Currently, this does not work, as it seems the built-in variable does not get expanded when set as the value of a plan variable.

2. When setting a branch variable, being able to select a built-in variable to override, so that, in this case, we could override the ${bamboo.buildNumber} variable on the develop branch with our static label.
fields.summary: override build-in vars or use built-in vars in plan vars

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
On the _Dependencies_ tab in _Plan Configuration_, if you want to search Child plan on its field, somehow Bamboo will automatcially add _undefined_ as the Child plan. The undefined will go away after refreshing the page, however it makes impossible to search for Child Plan.
!dependencies-undefined-bug.png!

*Steps to replicate*
# Install Fresh Bamboo 5.2
# Add some plan, say more than one plan, and navigate to _Plan Configuration_
# Go to _Dependencies_ tab and search for _Child Plan_
# Notice that the _undefined_ will be added under the Child Plan and it's impossible to search if Bamboo contains a lot of plans


The workaround for Bamboo 5.2 is to replace the existing BambooInstall/atlassian-bamboo/widget/autocomplete-controls/bamboo/plandependencies/plan-dependency.js file with the attached file and restart Bamboo.
fields.summary: Bamboo will automatically add "undefined" on the child plan field

fields.description: Use Clover core (com.cenqua.clover:clover) version 3.2.0
fields.summary: Update Bamboo Clover Plugin to core version 3.2.0

fields.description:
We are migrating our Bamboo DB and already have the link configured. During the wizard configuration, users can not only see but actively interact with the wizard screen through the builds tab. This should be blocked if possible. Or at least add a note to the documentation telling administrators to disable this link until the configuration is complete.

!Builds Tab.jpg!
fields.summary: JBAM - Builds tab in JIRA issues displays active wizard screen if Bamboo link configured

fields.description:
The steps to reproduce this:
# Create a version in JIRA and trigger a Bamboo plan when releasing that version in JIRA
# Navigate to the Bamboo build result page and manually link that build result to a JIRA issue
# Click on the linked JIRA issue key and you will see the null values as depicted in the attached screenshots.
fields.summary: JBAM - JIRA doesn't pull the build details from Bamboo if the Bamboo build is triggered by releasing a version in JIRA

fields.description: It would be really helpful if there was an option to tag all of our git repos whenever we created a release. This will make it easier to see what has changed between releases by comparing the tags. Can this please be added?
fields.summary: Tag when creating a release

fields.description: We have many SSH and SCP commands as part of our builds and deployment commands. It would be very helpful to like Git repos we can create shared credentials and logins for common hosts that are used in some of all of our tasks.
fields.summary: Add abiliity to store/share SSH keys for deployment and build tasks

fields.description:
I am unable to add a new instance AMI in bamboo because I cannot select a product, and the form fails to submit.

The form says:

Selected product "null" does not match detected platform

and provides no other error output. Additionally, this issue is not covered in any Atlassian docs.
fields.summary: Unable to select instance product in Elastic Bamboo
Password exposed in the logs

fields.description: It would be very helpful to be able to clone a deployment project, with environments, permissions, etc.Right now, it's quite an involved manual process.
fields.summary: Clone deployment projects

fields.description:
I'm a noob and probably wrong, but I saw this today and it confused me:

!https://monosnap.com/image/vLEXJtvEm7nKEl5EAFz78CHVu.png!

First it's weird that we have a deploy taking 1700 minutes, but I can deal with that.

Second, when I stop that deploy, it looks like the next oldest one will happen. Shouldn't we have a "skipped" state for all of the middle ones and immediately start deploying the newest one?
fields.summary: Concurrency control for deployments
Reduce verbosity of GitCommandProcessor

fields.description:
I have a deployment project with several releases (Payroll-2 through Payroll-7).  I can see the history of these releases (see screenshot).  If I edit my "Release versioning" it displays the next release as Payroll-8 as I expect (see screenshot).  If I click the "Create release" button from my successful build (see screenshot), on the "Create new release" page the "Last version", "This version" and "Subsequent version" fields are all incorrect.

Another (minor) anomaly is that instead of the radio button next to "#27 Manual run by Eric A. Zarko 2 mins ago" being selected, the text field is selected and populated with the value "27".  This will work, but seems erroneous as well.

I am using "version 5.2-beta1 build 4003 - 24 Sep 13".
fields.summary: "Create new release" isn't aware of current release

fields.description: Please update this plugin, so it's compatible with Bamboo 5.1.1 and 5.2 (that will be released soon): https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.sysbliss.bamboo.plugins.prepost-build-command
fields.summary: Update the Pre/Post Build Command Plugin

fields.description:
Root cause: Bamboo doesn't pass "java.version" system property when calling maven embedder.

Test case: put sth. like this in settings.xml
{code}
	<profile>
	  <id>blah</id>
            <activation>
	      <activeByDefault>true</activeByDefault>
	      <jdk>1.7</jdk>
            </activation>
	</profile>
{code}

Following error shows up in the logs:
{code}
....
16-Jan-2015 03:48:17	Finished task 'deploy' with result: Success
16-Jan-2015 03:48:17	Starting task 'auto dependency task' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.maven:task.mvn.dependencies.processor'
16-Jan-2015 03:48:18	Automatic Maven plan dependencies processing failed: org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuildingException: Some problems were encountered while processing the POMs:[ERROR] Failed to determine Java version for profile doclint-java8-disable @ com.abcd.platform:platform:2015.3-SNAPSHOT, /home/abcd/.m2/repository/com/abcd/platform/platform/2015.3-SNAPSHOT/platform-2015.3-SNAPSHOT.pom, line 77, column 20
16-Jan-2015 03:48:18	Finished task 'auto dependency task' with result: Failed
16-Jan-2015 03:48:18	Running post build plugin 'Artifact Copier'
16-Jan-2015 03:48:18	Running post build plugin 'npm Cache Cleanup'
...
{code}
fields.summary: Maven Dependency Plugin fails if you have "jdk" in profile activation

fields.description:
We would like to be able to automatically progress a release through environments.  For example:
* automatically deploy to Development on successful plan completion (can already do this) and trigger a bunch of testing
* automatically deploy to Performance on successful deployment to Development and all automated testing against development is successful.
fields.summary: Trigger for deployment based on successful deployment to another environment

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a plan that produces artifacts (Example: TestArtifact2)
2. In a different stage of the plan, use that artifact in a simple copy task. (Example: cp TestArtifact2 /Applications/Test)
3. Run the plan and notice that the artifact gets generated and copied to /Applications/Test correctly.
4. Now, delete the artifact definition in step 1, navigate to the location where the artifact generated in your last/current build is stored (Example: /Users/ssetayeshfar/Documents/bamboo-home-511/artifacts/SVNP-SVNPL/JOB1/build-00044) and manually delete the existing artifact. (You can also modify the script or have specific configurations that will not always generate an artifact in step 1).

fields.description: Migrating from HSQL to Postgres. Import fails with error. Able to test successfully on a local instance. Export file is attached.
fields.summary: Bamboo import fails with fatal error

fields.description: We do many selenium based tests and need to provide reports for robot framework output. We cannot migrate our system tests from Jenkins (which currently supports robot framework test results) without it. I'm sure we could generate the results in Bamboo but I'd like to avoid the humiliation (TIC) of posting our Bamboo-generated robot results to Jenkins for perusal and fail analysis.
fields.summary: Please provide reporting plugin for robot framework

fields.description: While configuring notifications for a deployment project, it would be helpful to have an option to receive emails for deployment failures separately. Right now, emails are sent for everything, and it can get overwhelming.
fields.summary: Failed deployment notificaitons

fields.description:
When using AWS VPC we can't set a certain elastic IP, only configure the IP's to ignore. 
When configuring the Elastic Images, we can set the subnet, but not the IP that we want to use with that image. 

Add the possibility to set the right address to each instance is a very welcome feature.
fields.summary: Add the possibility to assign a specific AWS Elastic IP when using AWS VPC

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
If you have plan key with only one character it will return 404 error upon clicking the plan to view plan details. By right Bamboo won't allow plan key to only have one character, but this could be achieved if the plan is imported from Jenkins. The proposed solution would be to warn or to prohibit the import if the plan key only contained one character.

*Steps to replicate*
You could either import plan from Jenkins with a plan containing one character as its key, or you could modify the plan key from database in {{BULD}} table and access the plan details from there.
fields.summary: If the plan key has only one character it will return 404 error

fields.description:
In JIRA hosted (behind the firewall) to release a version without building through Bamboo you must go to the Project Administration and the Versions screen. From there, click on the Cogwheel and select 'Release'. This will mark a version as released. But in the main screen there is a 'release' button that is only part of the Bamboo integration in OnDemand. Also selecting "build and release" in the instructions provided via the cogwheel provides the same error message.

That button makes customers really confused and users end up clicking on this button by mistake what provides an error message as you can see in the attached screenshot. 

Customer from JIRA Hosted would like to either remove the "release tab" from the downloaded version and go only with the cogwheel, or make the release button do the same as the cogwheel for downloadable versions.
fields.summary: Bamboo release button in JIRA Hosted

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
Some of the administrator would like to run agent without service wrapper from Adding agent panel in Bamboo administration. However it wouldn't work as the link would only return *Internal Server Error* page. Despite of that, you could still access the {{bamboo-agent-x.x.x.jar}} file through file directory in {{$BAMBOO-INSTALL/atlassian-bamboo/admin/agent}}. This issue didn't occur in Bamboo 4.4.5.

*Steps to replicate*
# Navigate to _Bamboo Admin >> Agents_
# If you haven't enable Remote agent capability, enable it
# Navigate to _Install Remote Agent_
# Under *Running the agents without the service wrapper* click on the bamboo-agent-x.x.x.jar

*Workaround*
Access the jar file through file directory, to be exact, it's inside {{$BAMBOO-INSTALL/atlassian-bamboo/admin/agent}} directory.
fields.summary: Direct agent jar link at "Running the agents without the service wrapper" returned Internal Server Error

fields.description:
We had a git authentication failure on bdog. 
https://bdog.atlassian.net/builds/browse/FUSE-WEBQF-36

So, the following error message appeared:

{noformat}
JIRA Fusion - CI JIRA DevStatus Plugin Webdriver Qunit Func Tests › FUSE-WEBQF-36 : Errors getting changes for FUSE-WEBQF-36
(java.lang.RuntimeException : com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitCommandException: command /usr/bin/git ls-remote https://my-user:clear-text-password@bitbucket.org/atlassian/my-repo.git failed with code 128. Working directory was [.]., stderr: [fatal: Authentication failed])
{noformat}

The password contains a "$", which appears in the clear text as "%24". So, it's pretty dangerous to have the password showed.
fields.summary: Git password showed as clear text when failing authentication
Add support for specifying additional MSTest parameters in the MSTest runner task

fields.summary: I can't access deployment builds

fields.description:
Deployment project (Deployment for First 510 Project) is triggered by a plan (First 510 Plan). 
I have a user that is part of a group - other than the bamboo-admin group. The user has:
1) View/Edit/Build/Clone/Admin permissions on the Plan
2) View/Edit/Deploy on the environment
3) View/Edit on the Deployment project

If I login with this user and select "Stop Deployment" when it's still running I receive an access denied error. 
* If the user is a bamboo-admin, selecting "Stop Deployment" correctly stops the deployment. 
* If the user is NOT in the bamboo-admin group and only has View/Edit/Build/Clone permissions on the plan, the problem still exists.
* If the deployment project is not triggered by the plan and is run manually,  the result is the same.

If we are planning to give a user all the admin permissions over a plan, the user can simply be added to the Admin group, but we still should not receive a permission error when all the right permissions exist. 

Please see the attached screenshots.
fields.summary: Access Denied error when stopping a deployment

fields.description:
Bamboo has some logic to automatically disable plans/branches after a # of failed attempts to poll the repository. By the way, this feature depends on some type of exception - so sometimes plans are disabled and sometimes not.

Allow this feature to be configurable (or possibility to disable this behavior).
fields.summary: Make Bamboo behavior customizable for automatic plan/branch disabling

fields.description:
Data about artifacts is counted once (including their size) and stored in the database (for multiple usage), but there is extra check to see if those files/directories still exist on disk. Condition for that right now is size()>0 and it seems like we have a bug here. We manually count the whole artifact size only to compare if it's bigger than zero. What we should do is return true after finding first not empty file to have the same behavior.

The attached jar file is a patch for Bamboo 5.0.1. Please replace the existing file from BambooInstall/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/lib with the provided jar and see if that makes any difference (after restarting Bamboo). The proper fix would be in Bamboo version 5.2 and higher.
fields.summary: Bamboo build summary page is slow to load because of the slowness of checking for artifact existence on disk
Bamboo throws "Failed to create EC2 security group" when it tries to start EC2 instance

fields.description: I wanted to edit a branch build but couldn't save it because of the error shown in the screen shot. I suspect this description was set via a plugin e.g. Fusion. IMHO Bamboo should reject that someone sets such a description.
fields.summary: Branch description can contain illegal characters

fields.description: We stopped shipping Oracle jdbc driver since Bamboo 5.1.0 (when we switched from the embedded Jetty to Tomcat). Is it a licensing issue similar to MySQL driver - [https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-11967]?
fields.summary: Oracle jdbc driver is not shipped since Bamboo 5.1.0

fields.description: There are no documents/guidelines for setting up Bamboo to run as a service after Bamboo 50. The page is deleted. Please either add information to: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Running+Bamboo+as+a+Service+on+Windows or create a new document.
fields.summary: Documentation for "Running Bamboo service on Windows as the local user" is missing

fields.description:
Hello,
I have the following problem according the testsuites tag in junit-xml reports parsed by the bamboo JUnit Parser:

If I have the same testsuite name, but in different testsuites, for example:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="iso-8859-1" ?>
<testsuites errors="0" failures="0" name="tests1" tests="156">
    <testsuite errors="0" failures="0" hostname="localhost" id="1" name="1 Summary" tests="156" ></testsuite></testsuites>
<testsuites errors="0" failures="0" name="tests2" tests="156">
    <testsuite errors="0" failures="0" hostname="localhost" id="1" name="1 Summary" tests="156" ></testsuite></testsuites>

..the second suite is not recognized by the parser.

I don't know, if the problem still occurs in Bamboo 5.0, but I have to use Bamboo 4.4.8 build 3511 - 11 Jul 13 for some plugin dependencies.
Is it possible to fix the problem without upgrading to 5.0?
fields.summary: [JUnit Parser] Problems with same testsuite name in different testsuites tags
Plugins are not properly installed on remote agents

fields.description: When there is a scheduled maintenance of bamboo it would be great if there would be a "placeholder" screen instead of Error 503 (telling there is a maintenance with a message from the administrator) ... Also, there should be the possibility to initiate maintenance from the bamboo admin screen, which would send a mail to everyone participating in the bamboo ecosystem
fields.summary: System maintenance message

fields.description: Agents screen put a small indicator regarding the disk free status of the host (green, yellow, red). I know this information is present in the host info, but if you have a lot of hosts you have to do a lot of clicks.
fields.summary: Indicator of space free on remote agents

fields.description:
On large instances of PostgreSql (with many plans) findPlanKeysFromAllOrphanedResultSummaries query runs very slow. It may be similar on other type of databases but it hasn't been confirmed.

Proposed solution is to remember builds remove in job so we don't search for them when removing build results.
After that create second job to run generic old removal of orphaned build results, but run lest often (proposed: daily)
fields.summary: Increase speed of the deletion service.

fields.description:
There is an issue with result summary page of rerun jobs which has NUnit Parser in it.
After every rerun a job's result summary page shows the list of successful tests from the first run, so if during later rerun some tests become successful, I don't see them in the list of successful tests.

Attached screenshots of this issue:
Run_1_Failed.PNG - 2 failed tests after the first run.
Run_1_Successful.PNG - 3 successful tests after the first run.
Run_2_Failed.PNG - No failed tests after the second run
Run_2_Successful.PNG - 5 successful tests in the header, but only 3 tests in the list.

On the last screenshot the list of successful tests must show all 5 tests, but it only shows successful tests from the first run.
fields.summary: Job result summary pager shows wrong list of successful tests after rerun

fields.description:
The automated Maven dependency management works great for detecting which plans are dependent on each other. This works very well.

However, this feature is next to useless when using multiple agents - especially the Elastic Bamboo agents. This is because when the triggered projects go to build, they can't find their dependencies.

As a manual work around, you can:
* publish the artefacts (build artifact and pom.xml) as Bamboo artefacts from the source project.
* download the artefacts in the destination project
* call 'mvn install:install-file' on the downloaded Maven artifacts so that they can be found during the build.

As a manual approach, this is very tedious, especially when setting up projects with several related dependencies.

All of this information is available to Bamboo, however, thanks to the Maven Dependencies Processor. That task needs a complement - a Maven Dependencies Artifact Downloader - which automates the steps described above.

(Note that this shouldn't require changes to the pom - unlike the deprecated Bamboo Artifact Sharing Maven Plugin)
fields.summary: Automated Maven Artifact Sharing

fields.description:
Our release process is such that in the begining of a release cycle, the release vehicle (aka release version number) is undetermined. A temporary codename is used as the release version.

As we get closer to Feature freeze, the official version is finalized and we need to update the build plan from it's code version to the official version.

There is a functionality in bamboo to "move" the build plan from one version to another version. However, as part of this move, changelist info on the build summary page , since last build before rename, seems to be lost.

We use perforce as our source code repository. It will be great if there's a way to rename build plan version without incuring missing changelists in the 1st build after the switch.

Steps to replicate the issue:

1. Administration>Plans>move plans
2. Destination Project: New Project
Project Name: <enter new project name>
Project Key: <enter new project key>
3. Check the plan to move
4. click 'move' button
5. provide new name and key
6. click 'done'.
7. Run the new plan.
8. Build summary does not list out the changelists since the last change.
fields.summary: Code change information missing after plan is 'moved'

fields.description:
Some of the administrator would like to have Documentation in Bamboo in regards of automatic startup or running Bamboo as service is Linux. They need to follow [JIRA documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Starting+JIRA+Automatically+on+Linux], and it might not come in handy if they are not aware that JIRA and Bamboo is currently using same application server which is Tomcat. 

\\
It would be better if it can be included inside [Bamboo installation guide for Linux|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+installation+guide+for+Linux]
fields.summary: Include run as Service tutorial in Bamboo Linux Installation Documentation

fields.description:
Stash Bamboo plugin requires a basic auth to be setup between Stash and Bamboo but if this is changed to have either OAuth or Trusted application link, the integration fails silently on Stash's side with no build status at all. There are no on-screen errors or indicators.

Only a message on Bamboo states:

"For Stash to receive this notification an Application Link is needed between the two systems."

[Knowledge base article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Bamboo+build+results+not+published+to+stash+and+an+NPE+is+thrown] for this issue.

Bamboo logs however report:
{noformat}
2013-10-10 12:05:02,277 ERROR [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-2-thread-3] [EventInvokerRunnable] Uncaught exception running event: com.atlassian.bamboo.event.ChainCompletedEvent[source=com.atlassian.bamboo.chains.ChainExecutionManagerImpl@12189646] plan=FP-FP and invoker com.atlassian.event.legacy.LegacyListenerHandler$LegacyListenerInvoker@34f4eb2
